race.name: Belgian Waffle Ride Kansas
race.tagline: The Hell of the (Mid) West—BWR's fall Midwest edition through the Flint Hills with 89% unroad.

logistics.explanation: Rebecca Fahringer admits "I had NO idea what to expect" and "no one told me how long this event was until literally the week before." Packet pickup runs Friday through Sunday at Sunflower Outdoor & Bike Shop with the Unroad Expo, but basic details remain sparse. Lawrence provides decent college town infrastructure, though the communication gaps suggest execution issues beyond the venue.

length.explanation: The 80-mile Wafer hits the sweet spot, though actual race distances vary—riders report "111 miles with over 7,000 ft. of elevation" and "123 miles with 6,823 feet of climbing" for the full Waffle. Three distance options (39, 80, 121 miles) accommodate different abilities. The length creates serious challenge without crossing into pure sufferfest territory. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The Snake Farm delivers "8-km of cyclocross inspired twists & turns, grass & berms, snakes & curves, and hills & bergs" that Rebecca Fahringer calls "the most glorious sector in any gravel or unroad race on the planet." Perry Lake Trails include sections where Jonas Orset notes "I need to dismount and carry the bike" with "sharp rocks" throughout the technical woods sections. More technical than most — comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: Riders report "nearly 2,000 meters (6,500 feet) of elevation on gravel roads" with the Snake Farm featuring "hills & bergs" that create race-defining selection points. The punchy profile with technical climbing through Perry Lake and the cyclocross course at Snake Farm delivers more than typical Kansas grinding. The undulating nature provides "repeated ramps for escape" according to Adam Roberge. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: October conditions prove challenging with start temperatures "around 43 degrees" that barely reach 55°F by midday. Riders face "steady 16 mph wind from the north" with "temperatures hadn't risen much above 50" creating energy-sapping headwinds. The "nonstop rainfall on Wednesday and Thursday" before race day creates variable surface conditions from hero dirt to mud. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Lawrence, Kansas sits around 900 feet elevation, making altitude irrelevant for performance. The course stays in typical Kansas elevation ranges without meaningful altitude effects. Wind becomes the primary atmospheric challenge rather than thin air. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The variety delivers from cyclocross barriers where "I need to dismount and carry the bike" through Perry Lake's technical woods to the Kansas River singletrack finale. Nicholas Roche describes it as "rediscovering cycling" on his first proper singletrack experience. The 89% unroad mix with private property access through Matt Gilhousen's Snake Farm creates exploration beyond typical gravel routes.

prestige.explanation: Elite fields include Rebecca Fahringer, Tiffany Cromwell, Nicholas Roche, and even Valtteri Bottas, with international riders traveling specifically for the event. Being mandatory for the BWRS Quadrupel Crown draws serious competitors, though Nicholas Roche's comment about "rediscovering cycling" suggests it attracts road pros exploring gravel rather than established gravel specialists.

race_quality.explanation: Course design creates dynamic racing with Adam Roberge calling it "the most dynamic and exciting BWR race in 12 years." However, 2021 saw navigation issues where "race organizers made a last-minute change" and "riders should follow course markings instead of the GPX file," causing confusion in the lead pack. The technical sections provide clear selection points.

experience.explanation: The weekend includes Michael Franti concerts, Unroad Expo, and Steve Tilford Foundation fundraising creating proper atmosphere. Riders enjoy "cyclocross barriers in true cyclocross fashion" with hecklers, plus "waffles at the finish and a Belgian finisher beer." The small-town integration in Lawrence's downtown core adds charm, though communication gaps frustrate participants.

community.explanation: The 2022 field of roughly 670 riders includes strong international presence and Michael Franti concert fundraisers for the Steve Tilford Foundation. Over 40 women compete across distances showing solid participation. However, basic race information gaps suggest organizational issues, and being newer to the gravel calendar means less established local community compared to regional stalwarts.

field_depth.explanation: Zero data on field size, past winners, or pro participation makes this a complete unknown. Being mandatory for the Quadrupel Crown should theoretically draw serious riders, but Kansas isn't pulling the same talent magnet as established gravel destinations. Without any historical results or pro rider mentions, you're gambling on whether you'll race against competition or just Crown chasers. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Elite Race Dynamics [2022] puts it: "This was by far the most dynamic and exciting BWR race in 12 years of Unroadiness."

value.explanation: The weekend package includes Michael Franti concerts, expo access, and Steve Tilford Foundation fundraising events beyond just the race. Course access to private property like Matt Gilhousen's Snake Farm and technical trail systems adds unique value. However, without published entry fees, total value assessment remains incomplete despite the extensive weekend programming.

expenses.explanation: Lawrence, Kansas provides affordable college town logistics without destination pricing. Fall October timing avoids peak travel costs, and the Midwest location keeps flights reasonable for most participants. Local lodging and dining remain budget-friendly compared to coastal gravel destinations, though entry fee pricing remains unpublished. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

final_verdict.one_liner: Kansas pretends to be Belgium with cyclocross courses and punchy climbs, but you're still riding through cornfields.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you've never experienced proper Belgian Waffle Ride suffering, this is training wheels for the real thing in San Diego or North Carolina. The cyclocross sections and singletrack will humble roadies, but seasoned gravel riders will find it more annoying than challenging. Show up undertrained and the punchy climbs will remind you that Kansas isn't actually flat.
final_verdict.alternatives: Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego delivers the full BWR experience with proper mountains and ocean views. Dirty Kanza/Unbound gives you authentic Kansas gravel without the gimmicks, while Mid South offers similar mileage with more legitimate suffering per mile.

course_description.character: Kansas decides to cosplay as Belgium with double the elevation per mile of anything else in the region. The Snake Farm cyclocross courses and punchy singletrack sections exist to humble roadies who think gravel is just riding fast on dirt roads. This is 89% unroad terrain designed to make you question why you didn't just stay in Flanders.

suffering_zones.label: Snake Farm Entry
suffering_zones.desc: First cyclocross course hits when your legs still feel good. Technical dismounts and barrier hops separate the cross racers from the weekend warriors.

suffering_zones.label: Singletrack Roulette
suffering_zones.desc: Narrow trails through northeast Kansas hills where your line choice matters more than your FTP. One mistake puts you in the weeds.

suffering_zones.label: Snake Farm Redux
suffering_zones.desc: Second cyclocross course arrives when your handling skills have degraded. The barriers feel higher and your legs feel like concrete.

suffering_zones.label: Punchy Finale
suffering_zones.desc: Rolling climbs stack up in the final miles. Each rise looks innocent until you're grinding in your easiest gear.

course_description.signature_challenge: The cyclocross courses through Snake Farm aren't just obstacles—they're skill tests at 50+ miles when your coordination is shot. You'll dismount, shoulder your bike, and remember why cross racers are quietly tougher than everyone else.
course_description.ridewithgps_name: 2022 BWR KS WAFER (copy) By 2023 BELGIAN WAFFLE RIDE

citations.label: RideWithGPS: 2022 BWR KS WAFER (copy) By 2023 BELGIAN WAFFLE RIDE

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Belgian Waffle Ride Kansas gravel race Lawrence

videos.title: 2021 Gravel Grinder Nationals | Lawrence, Kansas
videos.description:
#biggravelmiles #gravelrace
This was my first time racing this event and man, I have been missing out.  Everything about the event was top notch.  Great communication leading up to the race and very well run on race day.  There was a give away after the race with a ton of prizes AND they podium the top three riders in each each age group.  AND the champ in each age group gets a national championship jersey.  Hats off to Roger and crew for putting together such an incredible event.  I will be back!

Strava link to my race: https://www.strava.com/activities/6088838839

videos.title: Belgian Waffle Ride Kansas | THE HELL OF THE MIDWEST
videos.description:
#biggravelmiles #gravelrace #belgianwaffleride
The first ever Belgian Waffle Ride Kansas was crazy.  111 miles with over 7,000 ft. of elevation.  The course had everything.  Road, gravel, single track, cyclocross.  Elijah's chain basically exploded around mile 30 and somehow we were able to get it fixed, kinda, and roll to the finish.  This course itself was extremely difficult.  Throw in the wind and it made it extremely BRUTAL.  All in all though, it turned out to be a great day on the bike.

Strava link to race: https://www.strava.com/activities/6194458274

videos.curation_reason: Captures the inaugural BWR Kansas with vivid course details including single track, cyclocross sections, and brutal conditions.

videos.title: Belgian Waffle Ride Lawrence Kansas 2022
videos.description:
The final stop of the Quadruple Crown of the BWR series headed to Lawrence, Ks. I was hoping to salvage some semblance of an overall and also end my 2022 gravel season on a high note. Trying to figure out the long distance learning curve this year has been tough. The transition from pinner xc and CX events to long 6-7hr slogs has been a challenge. But my hopes were high and at the very least I'd get to hang out with Wally and Beck together for the first time all year. 

Wally and I finished 6/7th on the day and Becca won! It was both of their first BWR's and they walked away saying they would "for sure" look to do more of these next year. 

These videos take a lot of  time to make and sometimes the adventures are expensive. If you feel like donating to encourage/help me offset costs, THANKYOU! Your contribution is greatly appreciated and gives me the resources to provide y'all more content. 
Venmo: www.venmo.com/u/Kerry-Werner-1
paypal: https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/kerrywerner

https://bike.shimano.com/en-US/home.html
https://www.konaworld.com
https://www.maxxis.com/tires/bicycle

videos.curation_reason: High-quality pro rider perspective from Kerry Werner with strong production value and detailed race coverage.

videos.title: Can a Novice rider finish the Belgian Waffle Ride?
videos.description:
My brother and I attempted the 123-mile "Waffle" route of the 2023 Belgian Waffle Ride in Lawrence, Kansas. Watch this race recap to see if we're strong enough riders to finish the course with nearly 8,000 feet of climbing!

Event details: https://www.belgianwaffleride.bike/pages/kansas
My Strava ride: https://www.strava.com/activities/10038971095
videos.transcript:
hey there my name is Taylor this is a
recap of the 2023 Belgian waffle ride in
Lawrence Kansas my brother Rusty and I
signed up for the full 123 M waffle
route as our big end of season ride we
rode 63 miles at gravel Locos in May and
in the 5 months since then we have been
training about 10 hours per week good Lu
being at the start line with more than
400 other Riders was exciting even
though some of them were doing the
shorter routes I was eager to get
rolling partly because it was cold and
windy passing us on the left in the
yellow and red jersey is Drew dilman who
ended up finishing third you can see how
quickly he moves through the crowd to
get up with the front
rout unfortunately there was a little
bit of a bottleneck right here at the
start I think everyone made it through
all right but it's just a bit weird to
be dodging Porta potis and trucks at the
beginning of an organized
ride my brother and I had been training
All Summer in Texas so it was usually
sunny and the heat index was often above
100° that made the cool weather in
Kansas feel even colder to us uh it was
about 55° with up to like a 20 mph wind
out of the northwest so he and I both
bought a bunch of new cold weather gear
just for this
ride most of our training was on the
road we did do a few gravel rides but we
weren't as confident on the gravel as we
would have liked to
be this route had over 7,000 ft of
climbing with grades up to
18% during training we were lucky to do
half of that uh much climbing over an
entire week the steepest hill near us is
like in an 8% grade for maybe a tenth of
a mile our plan for this ride was to
hold 300 watts during the climbs so as
to avoid burning out way too early how
you doing today good the promotional
material for this event said it's as
much an eating competition as it is a
bike race and that's definitely true we
found it challenging to eat while riding
due to both the gravel and the hills the
food we brought was Cliff shop blocks
which are normally fine in the heat but
in the cold they became very difficult
to chew quickly so if I was going to do
this again I would bring something that
didn't require chewing just like
syrup this Rider on my left really
pushed hard on the climbs they kept
passing us on the uphills and then we
would pass them on the downhills
eventually they turned off for one of
the shorter routes so I think we made
the right call holding our 300 watts and
not trying to keep up with
them the aid stations were well stocked
with plenty of water and mix and food
the people manning them were friendly
and helpful too that being said I did
have two minor complaints the first is
that the drink mix while it did have
carbohydrates it was potato and rice
based rather than sugar based that
seemed like an unusual choice to me it's
not a drink mix that I'm used to and my
second complaint is that a lot of the
food had caffeine in it which made it
hard to balance getting enough to eat
with consuming too much
caffeine oh come on shift I sometimes
had a little bit of trouble shifting in
this instance I wasn't able to shift
into the smaller ring up front even
though I tried to that forced me to put
a foot down which made this climb much
harder and although I used every gear in
my drivetrain I can see why people run
one by setups having one less derailer
to worry about would really be
nice some of the downhills turned into
washboards about halfway down that made
it hard to maintain control while
keeping a reasonable speed and as you
can see with this guy sometimes your
bottles wanted to pop off the bike
fortunately for Rusty and me we never
lost any
bottles
I think we were both underprepared for
the more technical parts of this ride
we're both basically Ries and the double
track section wasn't too bad but I
really struggled on the single track
portion the trail is actually meant for
hiking instead of mountain biking so I
took it really slow through there to
make sure that I didn't crash also I
walked through the really tricky Parts
uh I had not practiced getting on and
off the bike quickly so that was
especially slow for me I'm sure cycl CLA
Riders did a lot better through this
section there he is after the single
track we had these nice connector paths
through some Fields it may look smooth
on video but the ground was surprisingly
bumpy still it was nice for things to
open up and not worry about running into
trees for a little while my brother was
waiting for me there because he heard my
disc brakes squealing in the distance
and knew I'd be
coming I should take a minute to
describe our goals so we had finished
gravel Locos in about 4 hours and that
was a 63m ride we also finished a 101
Mile Road ride in just under 5 hours so
we thought 8 hours was a reasonable goal
for this 123 M gravel ride Honestly
though for me I just wanted to finish
and thought maybe we'd take around 9
hours at this point we're about 4 and 1
half hours in we've done a little less
than half of the course so it might seem
like we're behind our 8 Hour goal but we
had been fighting a headwind basically
the whole time we figured that we could
make up some time once we turned around
and had that wind behind
us but before we could enjoy that
Tailwind we had to cross over this
Spillway the crosswind was strong here
since we're at the crest of a hill and
there's nothing to break the wind uh the
wind was so strong that it nearly blew
us over and I feel bad for that
photographer that just had to sit there
in the wind all
day most of the cars we encountered were
courteous and gave us plenty of room as
they passed but this truck towing farm
equipment passed close to us for
seemingly no
reason have on by the time we got got to
this intersection it wasn't still closed
two cars but there was someone in that
Lantern Rouge truck keeping an eye out
and talking to us through a PA they told
us to enjoy the hill which you know we
tried but then that dang truck with his
farm equipment somehow passes us again
except this time it was on a gravel road
and they passed us even closer than last
time I have no idea how they managed to
pass us twice especially since we were
going so much slower than them but the
Mind aside from Cars the other
excitement we encountered on the road
was dogs one of them charged right up to
us but then kept its distance um we were
worried about running into them or being
bit but fortunately neither of those
things happened and we were able to keep
riding in peace still it's not great to
come across loose dogs on a
ride between the two of us we only had
one crash all all day and it was very
lowkey the route had a lot of these
downhills that ended with a sharp turn
at the bottom of this one Rusty had a
bit of a problem and just kind of tipped
over fortunately both he and his bike
were fine we were able to get back up
and keep riding that was the only
unplanned stop all day no other crashes
or mechanical issues or flats or
anything like
that our plan was to roll past
this aid station because there was
another one in just 10 more miles uh it
didn't make sense to stop twice in such
quick succession so we went for the
later
one unfortunately for me around this
part of the race I started feeling not
very good maybe I hadn't eaten enough or
the unusual drink mix from the aid
stations wasn't sitting well with me
either way I was fading fast I li lied
my way to the aid station and gave up I
sat around eating there for like half an
hour and then one of the volunteers gave
me a ride back to the start line
although I was disappointed by not
finishing I'm still proud of what I did
uh it was perhaps the hardest bike ride
I have ever
done although that was the end of the
race for me Rusty kept riding for
another 2 and 1/2 hours to finish the
entire course I'm proud of him for
soldiering on through another 36 miles
including the final single track
section we both had a great time at this
year's Belgian waffle ride in Kansas it
was challenging but rewarding and maybe
next time I'll be able to complete
it thanks for watching please like And
subscribe for more cycling content I'll
see you in the next
one
videos.curation_reason: Recent 2023 race recap with specific details about the 123-mile course challenges and novice rider perspective.

videos.title: Belgian Waffle Ride Hell of the Midwest In Lawrence Kansas on Halloween
videos.description: Used my Epic Hardtail with Vittoria Terreno 2.1s,  36 round chainring w/ 10-52 cassette. Started mid pack thinking the Neutral Roll Out would be chill but is was nothing like that. Before I could even think about moving up the lead group was gone. Had a good day 7 hours  33 minutes of fast gravel and 3 sections of single track.

quotes.text: This route had over 7,000 ft of climbing with grades up to 18%. During training we were lucky to do half of that climbing over an entire week. The steepest hill near us is like an 8% grade for maybe a tenth of a mile.

111 miles with over 7,000 ft. of elevation. The course had everything. Road, gravel, single track, cyclocross. This course itself was extremely difficult. Throw in the wind and it made it extremely BRUTAL.

It was about 55° with up to like a 20 mph wind out of the northwest. We found it challenging to eat while riding due to both the gravel and the hills. In the cold the Cliff shot blocks became very difficult to chew quickly.

key_challenges.name: Cyclocross section
key_challenges.description: Technical dismount-and-run section that riders describe as crazy and challenging.

key_challenges.name: Lawrence River Trail single track
key_challenges.description: Single track section meant for hiking rather than mountain biking that requires very slow, careful riding to avoid crashes.

key_challenges.name: Double track washboards
key_challenges.description: Downhills that turn into washboards halfway down, making it hard to maintain control while keeping reasonable speed.

key_challenges.name: Technical climbing sections
key_challenges.description: Grades up to 18% with over 7,000 feet of climbing that challenge riders not used to steep terrain.

terrain_notes.text: Downhills turn into washboards about halfway down that make it hard to maintain control while keeping reasonable speed.
Single track portion is actually meant for hiking instead of mountain biking, requiring very slow, careful navigation.
Route includes both gravel and technical single track sections that are described as the most gnarly gravel race conditions.

gear_mentions.text: Can see why people run one by setups - having one less derailleur to worry about would really be nice on the technical terrain and steep climbs.
Bottles want to pop off the bike on the rough washboard descents, though some riders manage not to lose any.

race_day_tips.text: Hold 300 watts during climbs to avoid burning out way too early, rather than trying to keep up with riders who push hard on uphills.
In cold weather, bring food that doesn't require chewing like syrup - Cliff shot blocks become very difficult to chew quickly when it's cold.
Be careful with caffeine intake - a lot of the aid station food has caffeine in it, making it hard to balance getting enough to eat with consuming too much caffeine.
Watch for route changes and arrows - there may be rerouting around bridge closures that GPS doesn't reflect.

additional_quotes.text: It was about 55 degrees with up to like a 20 mph wind out of the northwest so he and I both bought a bunch of new cold weather gear just for this ride.
The aid stations were well stocked with plenty of water and mix and food. The people manning them were friendly and helpful too.
Things happen for a reason the three of us had an awesome day riding together - this event is insane but it's awesome in so many ways.

rider_intel.search_text: Belgian Waffle Ride Kansas features over 7,000 feet of climbing with grades up to 18%, making it extremely challenging for riders used to flatter terrain. The 123-mile full route includes technical sections like a cyclocross dismount-and-run portion and single track trails originally designed for hiking rather than biking. Riders describe washboard descents that make control difficult and steep climbs that demand careful pacing. Weather conditions included 55-degree temperatures with northwest winds up to 20 mph, requiring cold weather gear for many riders. The course features route changes and potential rerouting around bridge closures that GPS may not reflect. Aid stations are well-stocked with friendly volunteers, though the drink mix is potato and rice-based rather than sugar-based, and much of the food contains caffeine. Mechanical issues are common on the technical terrain. Riders consistently describe this as one of the most challenging gravel events, calling it insane but awesome.
